articles.headline: A Deal Maker With a Hot Hand Opens His Wallet
articles.snippet: At 77, Warren E. Buffett, the country’s most famous investor, is in the midst of his hottest streak in almost a decade. And he is capping his run with a flurry of deal-making.
articles.abstract: At 77, Warren E. Buffett, the country’s most famous investor, is in the midst of his hottest streak in almost a decade. And he is capping his run with a flurry of deal-making.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett is in no mood to quit.

articles.headline: China Lets Currency Appreciate a Bit Faster
articles.snippet: The increase fed speculation that China was yielding to international pressure and the state of its economy.
articles.abstract: The increase fed speculation that China was yielding to international pressure and the state of its economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  China’s currency rose steeply against the dollar this week, feeding speculation that Chinese authorities, yielding to international pressure and economic realities at home, were allowing their currency to appreciate more rapidly.

articles.headline: Harvard’s Aid to Middle Class Pressures Rivals
articles.snippet: Officials say expanded financial aid at Harvard may push other colleges to shift aid away from low-income students.
articles.abstract: Officials say expanded financial aid at Harvard may push other colleges to shift aid away from low-income students.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just days after Harvard University announced this month that it would significantly expand financial aid to students from families earning as much as $180,000 a year, William G. Durden, president of Dickinson College in Carlisle, Pa., got a query from a student’s father, asking whether the college would follow Harvard’s lead.

articles.headline: Instant Fortunes, and Sudden Headaches
articles.snippet: Suddenly coming into a lot of money isn’t necessarily the ticket to financial freedom.  Instead, it can be difficult to find smart, solid advice for handling it.
articles.abstract: Suddenly coming into a lot of money isn’t necessarily the ticket to financial freedom.  Instead, it can be difficult to find smart, solid advice for handling it.
articles.lead_paragraph: So what would you do if you got your wish and suddenly came into a lot of money  by winning the lottery, perhaps, or getting a six-figure insurance settlement or a long-awaited inheritance? Financial freedom, right?

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Pulls Plug on Movies via the Web
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart said it had ended the business because Hewlett-Packard, a chief technology partner, had decided to discontinue essential infrastructure for the service.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart said it had ended the business because Hewlett-Packard, a chief technology partner, had decided to discontinue essential infrastructure for the service.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Nearly a year ago, Wal-Mart Stores grandly announced plans to enter the movie download business. It has exited with much less fanfare.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Brad Stone

articles.headline: A Biracial Candidate Walks His Own Fine Line
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s postracial style is the reason for much of his political success, but it also has its pitfalls.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s postracial style is the reason for much of his political success, but it also has its pitfalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 2006 Democratic primary campaign for the presidency of the Cook County Board of Commissioners was vintage Chicago politics.

articles.headline: New-Home Sales Fell to 12-Year Low in November
articles.snippet: New-home sales fell 34.4 percent from a year earlier, the biggest year-over-year drop since January 1991.
articles.abstract: New-home sales fell 34.4 percent from a year earlier, the biggest year-over-year drop since January 1991.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home builders are sharply curtailing construction and cutting prices across the country as they struggle to break out of the worst housing slump since the early 1990s. But buyers remain scarce, and analysts say the market may not bottom out until well into next year or even later.

articles.headline: Beijing’s Olympic Quest: Turn Smoggy Sky Blue
articles.snippet: For the world’s Olympians, Beijing’s air is a performance issue. For the city’s estimated 12 million residents, pollution is an inescapable health and quality-of-life issue.
articles.abstract: For the world’s Olympians, Beijing’s air is a performance issue. For the city’s estimated 12 million residents, pollution is an inescapable health and quality-of-life issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Every day, monitoring stations across the city measure air pollution to determine if the skies above this national capital can officially be designated blue. It is not an act of whimsy: with Beijing preparing to play host to the 2008 Olympic Games, the official Blue Sky ratings are the city’s own measuring stick for how well it is cleaning up its polluted air.

articles.headline: Pakistan Asserts Link to Al Qaeda in Bhutto Death
articles.snippet: An official said there was a debate within the Bush administration over whether to press for an international investigation.
articles.abstract: An official said there was a debate within the Bush administration over whether to press for an international investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  As the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto was laid to rest, the government on Friday recast its version of the events of her assassination and announced that it had obtained an intelligence intercept pinning the attack on a militant linked to Al Qaeda.

articles.headline: Crisis Overseas Is Sudden Test for Candidates
articles.snippet: The assassination of Benazir Bhutto provides a rare unscripted test of presidential hopefuls’ geopolitical smarts.
articles.abstract: The assassination of Benazir Bhutto provides a rare unscripted test of presidential hopefuls’ geopolitical smarts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEBSTER CITY, Iowa  For the presidential candidates, the assassination of Benazir Bhutto has emerged as a ghoulish sort of test: a chance to project leadership and competence  or not  on a fast-moving and nuanced foreign policy issue.

articles.headline: Local Militants in Pakistan Add to Qaeda Threat
articles.snippet: The Qaeda network accused by Pakistan’s government of killing Benazir Bhutto is increasingly made up not of foreign fighters but of homegrown militants.
articles.abstract: The Qaeda network accused by Pakistan’s government of killing Benazir Bhutto is increasingly made up not of foreign fighters but of homegrown militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Qaeda network accused by Pakistan’s government of killing the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto is increasingly made up not of foreign fighters but of homegrown Pakistani militants bent on destabilizing the country, analysts and security officials here say.

articles.headline: Candidates Digging for a Deeper Pool of Iowa Voters
articles.snippet: The turnout effort among Democrats has exploded into the most ambitious and costly in the history of Iowa’s caucus.
articles.abstract: The turnout effort among Democrats has exploded into the most ambitious and costly in the history of Iowa’s caucus.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES  Senator Barack Obama is on the hunt for Iowans who have never participated in the state’s presidential caucuses, including independent voters under 50 and students who will be 18 by the general election.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Surge in Off-Roading Stirs Dust and Debate in West
articles.snippet: Federally owned lands are being transformed into the new playgrounds, and battlegrounds, of the American West.
articles.abstract: Federally owned lands are being transformed into the new playgrounds, and battlegrounds, of the American West.
articles.lead_paragraph: DURANGO, Colo.  In the San Juan National Forest here, an iron rod gate is the last barrier to the Weminuche Wilderness, a mountain redoubt above 10,000 feet where wheels are not allowed.
articles.byline: By Felicity Barringer and William Yardley

articles.headline: The Debt Crisis, Where It’s Least Expected
articles.snippet: A children’s charity says it wasn’t told of mortgage debt risks.
articles.abstract: A children’s charity says it wasn’t told of mortgage debt risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE Indiana Children’s Wish Fund, which grants wishes to children and teenagers with life-threatening illnesses, got an early Christmas gift nine days ago. Morgan Keegan, a brokerage firm in Memphis, made an undisclosed payment to the charity to settle an arbitration claim; the Wish Fund said it had lost $48,000 in a mutual fund from Morgan Keegan that had invested heavily in dicey mortgage securities.

articles.headline: Winners and Losers in a Year of Deal-Making
articles.snippet: A look at the winners and the losers behind the most notable mergers and acquisitions of the year.
articles.abstract: A look at the winners and the losers behind the most notable mergers and acquisitions of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLEASE take your seats, ladies and gentlemen.

articles.headline: Wall St. Way: Smart People Seeking Dumb Money
articles.snippet: Investors, looking for gold in hedge funds, have found dross.
articles.abstract: Investors, looking for gold in hedge funds, have found dross.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, buyout professionals are seen as the smart money. But their new shareholders are starting to look like the dumb money.

articles.headline: Radio’s Challenge: Counting the Young
articles.snippet: The electronic audience measurement tool, the “people meter,” has so far produced odd results.
articles.abstract: The electronic audience measurement tool, the “people meter,” has so far produced odd results.
articles.lead_paragraph: As radio moves away from an outdated system of audience measurement, it is facing the same problem that confronts other media: figuring out how many young people are listening or watching is maddeningly difficult.

articles.headline: Web Playgrounds of the Very Young
articles.snippet: Forget Second Life. The real virtual world gold rush centers on the grammar-school set.
articles.abstract: Forget Second Life. The real virtual world gold rush centers on the grammar-school set.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Forget Second Life. The real virtual world gold rush centers on the grammar-school set.

articles.headline: After the Pain of a Son’s Death, a Shared Mission in Politics
articles.snippet: John and Elizabeth Edwards’s decision to stay in the race despite her cancer drew on a lesson learned through pain.
articles.abstract: John and Elizabeth Edwards’s decision to stay in the race despite her cancer drew on a lesson learned through pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an instant, a world in which everything seemed right suddenly seemed all wrong. John and Elizabeth Edwards’s 16-year-old son, Wade, their first-born, was dead, with nothing to blame but the gust of wind that had flipped his car off a wide-open road.

articles.headline: Democrats Try Various Styles, and Pronouns
articles.snippet: The performances of Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and John Edwards reveal a basic thematic divide.
articles.abstract: The performances of Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and John Edwards reveal a basic thematic divide.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s appearances are not billed as anything so conventional as mere “rallies” or “town meetings” or “speeches.”

articles.headline: In the DVD War Over High Definition, Most Buyers Are Sitting It Out
articles.snippet: Even as prices fall, neither Sony’s Blu-ray nor Toshiba’s HD DVD, has gained an advantage.
articles.abstract: Even as prices fall, neither Sony’s Blu-ray nor Toshiba’s HD DVD, has gained an advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: What if nobody wins the high-definition DVD format wars? That increasingly looks to be the situation for the next-generation DVD technology, which is available to consumers in two incompatible formats.

articles.headline: New Questions Arise in Killing of Ex-Premier
articles.snippet: Indications that doctors felt pressured to conform to government accounts of Benazir Bhutto’s death added to the pressure for an international inquiry.
articles.abstract: Indications that doctors felt pressured to conform to government accounts of Benazir Bhutto’s death added to the pressure for an international inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan  New details of Benazir Bhutto’s final moments, including indications that her doctors felt pressured to conform to government accounts of her death, fueled the arguments over her assassination on Sunday and added to the pressure on Pakistan’s leaders to accept an international inquiry.

articles.headline: Jihadists in Jails Win Leverage Over Their Keepers
articles.snippet: Through protests, militant inmates in Morocco have won perks that make them the envy of other inmates.
articles.abstract: Through protests, militant inmates in Morocco have won perks that make them the envy of other inmates.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASABLANCA, Morocco  Ahmed Rafiki sprawled on the makeshift couch in his cell, a fresh red henna dye in his long hair and beard.
articles.byline: By Michael Moss and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: Awkward Encounters in the Hollywood Trenches
articles.snippet: During a strike, it’s enemies by day and friends by night.
articles.abstract: During a strike, it’s enemies by day and friends by night.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  A dozen striking screenwriters gathered in the bar at the Hotel Bel Air not long ago to decompress after another day on the picket line. Less than 10 feet away sat another strike-weary pair: Peter Chernin, president of the News Corporation, and Barry Meyer, chief executive of Warner Brothers.

articles.headline: Opposition Parties Vow to Proceed With Jan. 8 Election
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s largest political party picked Benazir Bhutto’s 19-year-old son to succeed her as chairman and vowed to forge ahead with elections next week.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s largest political party picked Benazir Bhutto’s 19-year-old son to succeed her as chairman and vowed to forge ahead with elections next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAUDERO, Pakistan  Three days after the violent killing of its leader, Benazir Bhutto, Pakistan’s largest political party on Sunday picked her 19-year-old son to succeed her as chairman and vowed to forge ahead with elections next week, immediately creating a new quandary for the government about whether to delay the vote.

articles.headline: Bloomberg Moves Closer to Running for President
articles.snippet: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is growing increasingly enchanted with the idea of making an independent presidential bid.
articles.abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is growing increasingly enchanted with the idea of making an independent presidential bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buoyed by the still unsettled field, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is growing increasingly enchanted with the idea of an independent presidential bid, and his aides are aggressively laying the groundwork for him to run.

articles.headline: Disputed Vote Plunges Kenya Into Bloodshed
articles.snippet: The dubious conclusion of the most fiercely fought election in Kenya’s history has pitched the country into chaos.
articles.abstract: The dubious conclusion of the most fiercely fought election in Kenya’s history has pitched the country into chaos.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya  It took all of about 15 minutes on Sunday, after Kenya’s president was declared the winner of a deeply controversial election, for the country to explode.
